DIV1.P: FONTAINBLEAU; OR, OUR WAY IN FRANCE.
A COMIC OPERA, IN THREE ACTS. AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRES-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN AND SMOCK-ALLEY, WRITTEN BY J. O'KEEFE, ESQ. THE MUSIC SELECTED AND COMPOSED BY WILLIAM SHEILD.
DUBLIN: Printed for W. WILSON, No. 6, Dame-street▪

LIST.ITEM: AIR. I. A Londre, I vas taylor nice, Page. 11
AIR. II. My morning of life, ah, how tranquil, how bright, Page. 13
AIR. III. The British Lyon is my sign, Page. 15
AIR. IV. Oh lingering time, why with us stay, Page. 19
AIR. V. Flow'rs their beauties all surrender, Page. 21
AIR. VI. Indeed I'll do the best I can, Page. 22
AIR. VII. The night when pass'd in golden skies, Page. 24
AIR. VIII. Brooks to your sources ah swiftly return, Page. 25

AIR. X. Search all the wide creation round, Page. 32
AIR. XI. Love does so run in my head, Page. 35
AIR. XII. Through circling swetts I freely rove, Page. 36
AIR. XIII. No burry I'm in to be married, Page. 37
AIR. XIV. I'm here in France, the more fool I, Page. 40

DIV1.HEAD: FONTAINBLEAU; OR, OUR WAY IN FRANCE.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. A Street.
DIV3.STAGE: Two Hotels.—The Sign of the Red Lion on one Side of the Stage, underneath the Name "HOTEL CASEY." —On the other Side the Fleur de Luce, "HOTEL GARNI."— (Ringing of Bells.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Casey.
SP.P: KEEP a sharp look out, Bob. The company tumble in upon us like smoke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lackland
SP.P: You rascal, I'll kick you down stairs. How dare you behave so to a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Heighday! what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Waiter entering.
SP.P: Oh, it's very well, sir, it's very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: What's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d waiter.
SP.P:
Only Mr. Lackland, madam. You know you ordered me to keep the Globe for the large company. There he takes possession of it; and though I told him it was bespoke, he would dine no where else; ordered a bottle of Champagne, and
because I did not fly with it, kicked me down stairs, though I cried, coming up, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Champagne without a louis in his pocket! the fellow has not a second coat to his back, and yet he's as proud as a Galway merchant. But I shall desire he'll quit my house.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Waiter.
SP.P: You desire! Ecod, madam, he says he'll make you bounce.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Make me bounce! he wou'd not find that so easy. Because I'm a lone woman, he thinks to impose upon me. A pretty fellow indeed! Make me bounce, will he!

SP.SPEAKER: Lackland .
SP.P: Where the devil are you all?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Don't you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lackland
SP.P: Where's that infernal—

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Waiter
SP.P: Infernal! Oh, madam, It's you he's calling.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Where the devil are you all? Where are those impudent waiter? Mrs. Casey, it is my desire—

SP.SPEAKER: Casey
SP.P: Your desire!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Yes, my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey
SP.P: A spunging fellow, giving himself airs. My waiters have enough to do, if they mind those who pay for what they call for.
SP.STAGE: (He takes snuff from her in a pet.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: And even your snuff too—is execrable.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey
SP.P:
Lookee, Mr. Lackland, every body knows that you're a gentleman—and that you've a good estate, only it's all gone;—and we all know too, that you're a six bottle man, and a choice companion. Now, during the races, I'll give you a seat at the table d'Hote, and put money in your pocket to pay your reckoning, if you'll only entertain the company
with a funny song and a comical story. Oh! a good song at the end of a bottle is an excellent thing, and of great service to a house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Live by entertaining company! Mrs. Casey, you're a widow; why don't you marry? You'd oblige me exceedingly if you'd marry again.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Marry again! for what?—Why do you wish me married again?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: That I might have the superlative felicity of taking your husband by the nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Oh! I wish I had a husband for your sake. I wish I had a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: There's a Paris chaise just stopped, and the lilly of France is after them already.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: The devil take that lilly! He'd grasp every thing if he could.—Who is there in it?

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: An English family.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: An English family! Do you run and en∣deavour to bring them here, while I go and prepare for their reception. (Exit Waiter.) Oh, my lad, I wish I had a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Postboy.
SP.P: Ah monsieur, too petite lousone.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Never satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Postboy.
SP.P: Seven posts, de post royal from Paris to Fontainbleau.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: There; seven you say. Now I hope you're satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Postboy.
SP.P: Ay, dis bon.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: But if we approach the mansion of the grand monarch, we must pay for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: By heaven, my college chum, Harry Seymour!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Pray, friend, can you tell me—Eh! why —I heard something of this before. Can you be Charles Lackland?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: How d'ye do, Harry?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why sure my eyes deceive me! Why you look—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: Never mind the outside. In snow or sun∣shine I've always a warm heart to an old friend and a new bottle.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I've passed so many happy days with you that I seel for you. exceedingly. But what is the cause of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: Pho! pho! never mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What all gone, Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: All, all, Harry.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What, at play?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Ay, play and pleasure—and wine and women—and—But you're come to sport here at the races, flush, flush, eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why, as to cash, my affairs are little better than your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Damn'd unlucky that for both of us.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: No. You see me here an exile forced to fly from my native country. You remember my sister Rosa—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: What, my little, mad Rosa, that used to steal our fish, and throw the cards into the fire? Either I dream, or there was a match talked of between her and lord Winlove.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P:
There was; but guidde by the weakness of her sex, and the arts of ours, he prevailed on her to set out for this country. I overtook them at Rochester, and demanded (perhaps too rashly) repa∣ration
of my sister's honor by an immediate mar∣riage. He refused. Pistols were the umpire. He lost his life; and the coroner's verdict has made mine doubtful if sound in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Bravo! shot a lord! I wlng'd a marquis the day before yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: In this dilemma I was forced to assume the habit of a woman to escape from my native country.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Where's Rosa now?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I brought her to France, and left her at the convent at Villeneuve. But to say the truth, I'm here at Fontainbleau in quest of a lady I fell in love with at the Sunday opera at Paris. She would not tell me her name, but talked something of her brother having horses to run here, whither she was coming.

DIV3.P: Whether is monsieur Lackland? —I must and I vill see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Oh, this damn'd French taylor! Now shall I be dunn'd and pester'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lapoche.
SP.P: Ah, monsieur Lackland, I am glad I have found you. I say I will not trust any longer, for dey mon—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I say (stopping his mouth) Lapoche, do you see that English officer? He's full of cash; and I'll recommend him to lodge with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: English officer! Oh, de bon new customer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Captain! that little, ugly, ill-looking fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ver much oblige to you—

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: If you want a taylor and a lodging, here's your man, and there's his house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Tank a you, monsieur Lackland.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: You'll find it convenient, as you're short of cash.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ver obliging.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Because when he asks for his money, you may kick him down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ver much oblige to you indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: 'Twas my way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Vastly kind indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: We were very good friends. Lapoche. I was a good customer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oui, monsieur, it does a tradesman's heart good to see a you—out of his house

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: What was it I gave you a week? Eight livres wasn't it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oui, monsieur, you did inteed—promise me eight livres.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Eh! Faith, I see some ladies. I must attend where beauty calls; afterwards I am yours from a beef-steak to a bottle of Burgundy. You must ex∣cuse me, Harry, the ladies—you know I was always a Philander among the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oui, you was always great gander indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: So you speak English; you've been in London?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Yes, I was ver great man in Londre, but now I am anoter man.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Another man!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: England is de grand field of battle for the soldier of fortune. I vas de taileur, de cook, de jugler, take off a de shirt, de maitre d'hotel, de tooth-drawer vid a touch; but at last my lor forget to pay a me, so den I did imitate my lor, and when I could no longer fight a my way—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: What then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Why den, I run away.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: So you have a character for every country. And pray what are you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: My true character, a tailleur.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A taylor!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oui, monsieur, at your service.

L.HI: A Londre, I vas taylor nice,
And work for lor so gay,
He never beat me down my price,
But den he never pay;
From lor I could no money get,
My draper wou'd not stay;
So, like my lor, I run in debt,
And den I run away.
Vid trick on card, I please my lor,
He wonder how I do't,
And ladies, all, my skill adore,
Ven cock in glass I shoot.
De British guinea I command
My pocket to recruit,
I shirt it off by sleight of hand,
Shirt off by sleight of foot.
Now here en France, I have no dread
For lor to move my shear,
For here in France, dey cannot plead
De privilege of peer.
Monsieur, if you employ a me,
And pretty coat vou'd vear,
Your little tailleur here I be,
Très humble serviteur.
To touch the little ready pelf
I sell the cordial drop,
But none would drink except myself,
So I shut up my shop.
Of chimney-sweep the tooth so white,
In noble mouth I pop,
My lor he grin, and den he bite,
Bon jour, and off he hop.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: A taylor, and come to sport your louis upon the jockies of France?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: No, I am come here to sport de jacket upon de jockey; de blue, de red, de green, de orange de emperor's eye, upon the jockey of France. Who give de grand brilliance to de race but de tailleur? Dey may talk of de boot and de spur; but de beauté of de race is oblige to de shear and de timble.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: This unfortunate duel! to be forced to live here, an exile from my native England—I wish, like my unhappy sister, I could find a comforter in oblivion.

L.HI: My morning of life, ah, how tranquil, how bright!
No care found a place in my breast;
My noon now is evening, and soon must be night;
A night without comfort or rest.
The floods bow resplendent with clear azure skies!
Tho' tempting, —too late, to his cost,
Beneath, for his heaven, who wantonly tries,
In streams of false pleasure is lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Pray which is the hotel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Hotel! Why, von't you lodge at my house —de bon apartment?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why, faith, at this time, as I wish to be as private as possible, I think that will be the best way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Von't you look at my logement?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Dis way if you please. But I won't let him see my new lodger, my little Rosa, because I mean to have her myself. Nannette, shew a de apartment to the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John
SP.P: Why how far farther do you mean to jolt us over these damn'd stones?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Waiter.
SP.P: This way, your honour.—Madam, here's Sir John Bull, my Lady Bull, and the whole family.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Ay, this is the truth of an English family.!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir John and Lady Bull, sherved in by the master of the Lilly, with porters, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: French Inn-keeper.
SP.P: Welcome from Paris!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Welcome from Paris!—Why how sat farther are you taking us over this damn'd pave∣ment?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Fie, Sir John, consider where you are. When gentlemen come to France, they always leave their damme's at Dover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I wish I had left you or myself there, damme.—Who the devil are there?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Why don't you see the gentlemen are porters.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Porters! pickpockets. Paid by the ounce. Why, one of our Thames street porters would carry ten times as much; and here's a proof of it. What, Robin, you've got my trunk I see.

STAGE.HI: Enter Coachman, with a large trunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Yes, your honour, four mounsheers had it, but they dropt it in the dirt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Robin, when you've carried it in, you must find out colonel Epaulette. Give our compli∣ments, tell him we are come, and desire to know how he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes, and if Sir Shenkin ap Griffin is at his house, tell him too that we are come, and that Doll is impatient to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Dolly! why Dolly Bull!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly
SP.P: Here, mamma.—Pray, mamma, which is the inn?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Inn! hotel, miss, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Miss! mam'selle if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well said, Doll; there's French upon French for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bull.
SP.P: Pray, monsieur, will you do us the favour to shew us to the hotel?

DIV3.STAGE: To the master of the Lilly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Favour to shew us to the hotel! How polite we are, and to a waiter, only because he's French!—Ay, come shew the larder, for I'm devilish hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Master.
SP.P: Dis vay, if you please, mademoiselle. I keep a de lilly of France, where you may have de ragout, de fricassee, de Vermicelli soup, de salad.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Waiter, carry the roast beef up to the Lion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, and carry me up to the Lion too!

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Oh, to be sure, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: So this is your house, eh! And you are English?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: English! that's what I am. I was born in Dublin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And pray what's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Casey, at your service; and I keep the Lion of England here.

L.HI: The British Lion is my sign;
A roaring trade I drive on;
Right English usage, —neat French wine
A landlady may thrive on.
At table d'hote, to eat and drink,
Let French and English mingle,
And while to me they bring the chink,
Faith, let the glasses jingle;
Your rhino rattle, come
Men and cattle, come
All to Mrs. Casey,
Of trouble and money,
My jewel, my honey,
I warrant I'll make you easy,
When drest and seated in my bar,
Let squire, or beau, or belle come,
Let captains kiss me, if they dare,
It's, Sir, you're kindly welcome!
On Shuffle, Cog, and Slip, I wink,
Let rooks and pigeons mingle,
And if to me they bring the chink,
Faith, let the glasses jingle.
Rhino rattle, come, &c,
Let love fly here, on silken wings,
His tricks I still connive at;
The lover who would say soft things,
Shall have a room in private.
On pleasure I am pleas'd to wink,
So lips in kisses mingle,
For while to me they bring the chink,
Faith, let the glasses jingle.
Your rhino rattle, come
Men and cattle, come
All to Mrs. Casey;
Of trouble and money,
My jewel, my honey,
I warrant I'll make you easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Bravo! Mrs. Casey. Introduce us to your roast beef. Come along.

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt all but Sir John, who drives the French porters before him, then comes forward on seeing Lackland]

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Sir John Bull's family. I hear they're from the city. Voulez vous parlez?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Don't parley me. I'm an Englishman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I see you are, by that honest face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Honest face! Well, and what have you got to say to my honest sace, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: The devil take me if I have any thing to say, but how do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Pretty well, I thank you, how do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Well, and pray how do all our friends in Throgmorton-street?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Throgmorton-street!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Sir, I am happy to see you. My heart warms at the sight of an Englishman, and I'm always happy to do them any service. I am English, sir, but a little unfortunate, or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What, you're poor, eh! Yes, faith, you're a little seedy. Have you no estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I have bad.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And what have you done with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Turned it into money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, and pray what have you done with that?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Laid it out to advantage, bought ex∣perience.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Bought experience! Why then by this time you're a damn'd witty fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Yes, fir, I know the world. I have had mansions, arables, freeholds, leaseholds, slewards, wastes, leases, releases, pastures, quarter-days, and such damn'd incumbrances.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: And so you've got rid of 'em all. It's all gone, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Every acre.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why you're a devilish clever sellow. And why did'nt you get your teeth drawn at the same time?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Very smart and clever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Because by this time I suppose you've no use for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Damn'd ignorant old dog! (aside) But, sir, you're just come to France, that is, you're a stranger here. Sir, my heart warms at the sight of my countryman; and 'tis my greatest pride and pleasure to warn honesty of the deceits practised here. Some of our own countrymen appear very serviceable and obliging; but their assiduity always ends in borrow∣ing money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir. I'm very much obliged to you.— Sir, will you eat a bit of mutton with us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Whith all my heart; but, sir, as there are ladies, this coat is not quite the thing to appear be∣fore the ladies in. There, do you see that taylor's over tae way? I have a devilish good suit lies there for a trifle. Will you be so obliging as to lend me a guirea, just that I may appear like a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A guinea! suit! eh!—Oh! what till the arables coat back? (lawghing). Disstress to be sure in a stronge coutry is very hard. What's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Lick.
SP.P: Lackland, at your service, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Lackland, there's a guinea for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I fancy, Sir John, I may pats very well in these clothes, eh!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Pass! Oh, yes, you may—for a shop∣lister

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Sir John, if you'll give me leave, I'll treat you with a flask of most excellent Champagne.— Walter, a bottle of Champagne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Here's a rascal! Treat me to Cham∣pagne! my own money too—and I doubt if the rascal has got a shirt to his ruffles.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: I say, my old friend (putting his hand on his shoulder above all beware of strangers—be sure you mind my advice—they're cursed assiduous, though it always ends in borrowing money, and laughing at you afterwards—Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! And laughing at me afterwards. That's a good joke—ha! ha! ha!— damn'd impudent fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: Now you know their ways, be sure you keep a tight hand upon your cash. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I shall, depend on't; especially if they mention Throgmorton-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: True, true, ha! ha!—I'm thinking, ha! ha! —how surprised you'll be when I pay you this guinea to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes, I shall be surprised indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: You see, ha! ha! l've fold all my arables, and have bought experience wholesale.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes; and now you retail it out at a guinea a dose, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Ha! ha! Bless that jolly face!—How a laugh becomes you! ha! ha! (taking hold of it.) I shall for ever acknowledge myself your debtor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I date say you ever will, ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Here, waiter, shew a room. A bottle of Champagne, and change for a guinea.

DIV3.STAGE: Exit laughirg, and taking bold of Sir John's arm.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE A room at Lapoche's.
DIV3.Q: Canst thou forget what tears that moment fell, When warm in youth, I bade the world farewel? As with cold lips I kiss'd the sacred veil, The shrines all trembled, and the lamps grew pale.
DIV3.P: Poor Eloisa in her cloister spoke my sense. I begin to repent my elopement. My lady abbess has ere this discovered it. I wonder if lord Winlove has received my letter. I hope it did not miss him. I wish he was come.

L.HI: Oh, lingering time, why with us stay
When absent love we mourn!
And why so nimbly glide away
At our true love's return!
Ab, gentle time, the youth attend,
Whose absence here I mourn;
The chearful hours in pity send
That bring my love's return.
I feel my heart with rapture beat;
No longer shall I mourn;
My lover soon with smiles I'll meet,
And hail bis dear return.

DIV3.P: Hey! sure my lord Winlove himself!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Winlove.
SP.P: My charming Rosa!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa
SP.P: My lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: But, my dear Rosa, how could you come to such a public place as Fontainbleau; and at such a time, when there are so many English fami∣lies? Fifty people may know us.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: If I had remained in the village, the lady abbess would have discovered me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Your letter says you escaped from the convent in boy's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Yes, and I was obliged to change them be∣fore I reached Fontainbleau, to elude all search from Vileneuve.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: And how unlucky to get into the house of Lapoche! such a busy, talking taylor!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa
SP.P: I did not know what lodging to get. 'T was better I thought, than being at a hotel. I with I was any where else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P:
Don't sigh, my Rosa; for though I was not to be threatened into a marriage by the young Chamont your brother, when he overtook us at
rochester; yet I shall with pride acknowledge you Lady Winlove on my return to England.

L.HI: Flow'rs their beauties all surrender,
When the sun withdraws his ray;
Now they shine in borrow'd splendor,
Painted by the beam of day.
With each good fair Eden planted,
Ev'ry sweet that sense could move;
Passion sighs tho' all is granted,
No enjoyment without love.
Dearest maid, thy smiles beslowing,
Bright and gay my hours shall be;
By this heart with rapture glowing,
Thou art light and love to me!

DIV3.P: The story of your brother's killing me is every where believed; therefore I mean to leave Fontainbleau, and by a cross route reach Paris.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Oh, my lord, I shall never forgive myself for this wicked, impious step.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: The impiety was mine, my Rosa, to rob heaven of an angel.

SP.SPEAKER: Nannette.
SP.P: Oh, madam, my master has brought in a new lodger, a young officer, and our countryman.— Oh, dear! I did not know this gentleman was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: An English officer! I'll instantly order a postchaise, for your removal from this group of jockies, grooms, peets and pickpockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Madam, look here, come and have one.
SP.STAGE: Kisses her hand to be heard.)

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Oh fie, Nannette. When that gentleman returns, vou'll call me to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Lord! how nice we are! I've a great mind to win the gloves myself (going.) Lord! he wakes!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry
SP.P: This travelling by night is very fatiguing. I thought to have slept in the chaise, but was disappointed by the jolting on the road.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Did you call, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ay. Who are you, my pretty lass?

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: My name is Nancy, sir; but my master will cal! me Nannette after the French fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Oh then, you're fille de chambre to the master of this lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: At your service, sir.

L.HI: Indeed I'll do the best I can
To please so kind a gentleman:
To lodge with us, and you shall see
How careful poor Nannette will be;
So nice, so neat, so clean your room,
With bow pots for the sweet perfume:
A'n't please you, sir,
When you get up,
Your coffee brown
Inchina cup,
Dinner, dessert,
And bon souper:
Sur mon honneur, at night you be
With waxen taper lit to bed
By poor Nannette your chambermaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Here's fine doings in my house!—Oh, fie, Nannette, why do you come here singing? Oh, you jade, I'll—Hope you had a good fleep, sir.—Get out! Vat do you come here for?— I'll knock a his head—Hope you refresh ver much after your sleep, sir—Get out—go yonder, dat vay— I hope you like your lodging—Get out, Nannette— (he pushes her off.)—Curse a dese red officier; de girls so fond—you'll find a my house ver convenient. You may have a de von, two course—de petite chanson; invite whom you please, your countrymen eat, drink, sing, roar, be so jolly, swear and knock a your fists against von another's head, a la mode de Londrèe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Sir, monsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Nannette, vhy do you come dis vay, peeping at de man in de red coat? Get out

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Get a you gone, you jade—I know ver well vat you want. You come peeping at de officier. Vhy you come peeping at de men?

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Lord, sir, I had a message. Sir Shenkin ap Griffin has sent for the new jackets for the jockies; and Colonel Epaulette has sent to know if the English liveries are made.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Dese are my grand customer (to Henry). Vill you get out of de vay? (to Nannette). Sir Shenkin is ver great man. I make a de jacket for de race.— Get a you first, Nannette—Dis vay if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: I wonder what should keep lord Winlove so long. I'm surprised he does not return. Should he and my brother meet—this suspence is tor∣menting. Would we were on the road! Yet why do I wish to see England, when those whom most I love are in this kingdom!

L.HI: The night when pass'd in golden skies,
If whiten'd cliffs the sailor spies
The sailor spies, completely blest;
The sight each tender though inspires,
His love's on sbore, and fancy fires,
And fancy fires his faithful breast.
The dancing waves salute his oar,
He pulls, and sings, my love's on shore,
He waves his hat, and cries adieu,
Farewell, good ship and loving crew,
Farewell, good ship, for love I steer,
And as around he turns his face,
To view the happy, well known place,
The happy place that holds his dear,
He pulls and sings, my love's on sbore.

SP.SPEAKER: Nannette and Henry .
SP.P: The lady desires not to be seen by any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I will come in. The boy said the lady was impatient to see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: What do I see?—My brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: My sister Rosa!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: My dear brother, though appearances are against me, yet when you're acquainted with the circumstances, you'll forego your resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Why did you quit the convent where I placed you, that you might find an asylum for your shame?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: My dear brother, if you knew some parti∣culars, that prudence sorbids me to mention—

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Talk not of prudence. Are you not lost to every sense of virtue? And have you not involved me in a misfortune, that will for ever disturb my peace?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa .
SP.P: He don't know that my lord is alive; and I dare not inform him, lest his ill-placed passion should relapse.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I'll lodge you safe at Villeneuve once more. And yet, as my charmer said she was coming to the races, if I quit them without finding her, I may never see her again. But my sister must go to the abbess, and I shall desire her to strengthen your spiritual claims—and yet love so sympathizes in my own breast, that I'll chide no more.

L.HI: Brooks, to your sources ah swiftly return,
Tear drop on tear, and give life to the urn;
Truth and virtue pass away,
Ere I for another my true love betray.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. View of Fontainbleau Race Course.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Shenkin ap Griffin and Jockey, several other Stablemen, with cloths, bottles, rubbing sticks, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: YOU are a pig plockead. You have done very pad inteed.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: I won the race; what would you have me do more?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Won the race! You should have tis∣tanced his Plack Prince with my Merlin.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Why, if I had pushed so hard, I should have lost the first heat, when I was so cock-sure of winning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Cock-sure! Dick, don't tell me of your Yorkshire tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: Why then I say it was quite the policy of the thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Policy! follies! His Joan of Arc is to run against my Winney, and if you had tistanced, I should have had all the long odds in favour of my own horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dick.
SP.P: I did the best I could: I won the race; and if you arn't satisfied, you may ride the match yourself to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P:
Tid your pest! Get out, you imper∣tinent—goot jockies should know how to tistance, to
win, or to lose. Ay goot jockies should know how to lose as well as to win.—My Merlin is full brother to Winney; and if he had tistanced to-day, I should have taken in the whole field to-morrow, man, wo∣man and child.—Oh, here comes Mr. Lackland, the shentleman ragamuflin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Ay, give you joy, my boy Shenkin

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Shoy is a fery pretty thing, Mr. Lackland, pecause it kives pleasures; put your kiving me shoy py the name of poy, does not kif me plea∣sures: for look you, Mr. Lackland, I am a man and a shentleman; my name is Shenkin ap Griffin, Paronet; and I am of as high a tescent—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: As ever came from the mountains. Ay, come, Sir Shenkin, you and I are both of us very good blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I know you are tescended from Welch extraction py the mother's side; put my fa∣mily, look you, is as creat and as antient, look you, as any in the county of Flint.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Come, Mr. Welchman, don't strike your flint against me: if you do, I shall take fire.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, I think you would take fire inteed, for your coat is tinder. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Come, come, though you won the race, don't ride the high horse with me, but start some other subject for your jokes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Why yes, as you say, 'tis rather a threadbare subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Well, sir, I wish you'd have done with your jokes; if not, I—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Pless my soul! I to always put myself into a goot humour with my jokes. Put come, kif me your hard. If I tid laugh at your coat, I will get you a petter. Ha! ha! ha!—Look you yonder, my eye is your wardrobe. I have a coat in my eye for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Who is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Colonel Epaulette.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel
SP.P: Rule Britannia, Britannia rule the waves, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Oh! 'tis the English Frenchman, that I have heard so much of.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Ay, there he koes as merry after his teseat, as if he was dancing to parson Morgan's fittle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: They say he has a most benevolent nature, that he's very sond of the English, and wishes to learn all out customs and manners, and style of doing things.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, and he loses his money, and is as happy as if he won. I am his preceptor, and to teach him all polite accomplishments, the English customs and language.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: You teach—I suppose then by this time he can smoke, swear, and play at cricket.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Perhaps he may; and he has twenty thousand a year pesides.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Introduce me to him. I like a man that has twenty thousand a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Ay, he is your mark. Ha! ha! ha! He's in spirits, and thinks himself very clever if he interlards his confersation with a dozen tamme's.

Q.L: Of a noble race was Sir Shenkin
In de land of Mr. Tudor.

DIV3.P: Your servant, Sir Shenkin, your servant. Your Merlin did peat my Plack Prince for five tousand, so dere they are, damme—one tousand bank of Paris, two tousand bank of England, one Drummond, and one Child.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Sir Shenkin, as I've none of my own, if you please I'll adopt that child.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: A very good joke! Ha! ha! ha! Sir, with your leave and your likings, this is Mr. Thingemmy—Mr. Thingemmy, this is Colonel what-d'ye-call'em, and now you know one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Colonel What-d'ye-call'em, your most obedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Mr. Thingemmy, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Colonel, this is your preceptor, to fight your duels, or carry on intrigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir, ven my king does not command me to be your enemy, I shall be very happy to be friends with your English nation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: That's right; he's a tutor for you. He's a man of wit I assure you. Faith! he lives by his wits (aside). He has slats and sharps for the shentlemen, and smiles for the ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: No, no, sir; you see what I am, an ordinary fellow. To be sure, now and then I do come out with a little sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir, I shall be ver proud to be introduced to your little Sally.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P:
Sir, your most obedient, with pleasure. To be sure, now and then the ladies do squint at me a little. Just now, as I passed along what-dy'e-call e'm street, there were five or six peeping out at the windows. There he is, says one. Ay, that's him, says another. Oh! 'tis the English ambassador, says the third. No, no, says a sourth, 'tis the Em∣peror
incog. That it is, says another. So they all agree, nem. con. that I'm the Emperor incog.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Mr. Emperor, I will help you to a coat to carry on the war. I will new robe your imperial majesty. (aside to Lackland.)—I say, Colo∣nel, get rid of yoar tinsel, and ket a coat more in out style, ha, Lackland!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I own I was always partial to the New-market style.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I think his coat is in the old-market style.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Why 'tis rather—Upon my soul, you've a devilish deal of wit. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir, you do me great honour. Will you eat a bit of dinner with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Sir, I'll breakfast, dine and sup with you. Sir, I'll stay a month in your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, and you'll find it tamn'd hard to ket him out of your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Indeed! Sir, you are de most hospitable fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Is that your suler Celia? I had not seen her some time. She's a charming girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, she was a fine girl, but her Paris education has spoiled her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I shall dance with her to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Inteed you won't, for Celia has mo∣neys, and you are poor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Well, has her money spoiled her dancing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P:
No, put tancings pring palmings, and palmings pring matrimonies; and you must not marry into the ap Griffin's. Only suppose now to yourself I am her guardian. So, Mr. Mogul, don't drop your handkerchief at my sister. I find you've thrust your
nose into Sir John Pull's Family; and I will advise you to keep out of the field there too.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir John Bull! dat is de famille dat is re∣commend to me from his grace de duke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: You advise! why so? Oh! I hear you are to marry miss Dolly Bull; but where's the Welch pride there? What! mix the blood of Cadwallader with the puddle of Thames-street?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Look you, Mr. Lackland, I know my pops and sharps as well as you; so let's have none of your London tricks there.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Oh charming London!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Ay, London for ever, colonel!—I'll kive you my idea of it. Now, you must fancy me a puck or a plood, look you.

L.HI: In London my life is a ring of delight,
In frolicks I keep up the day and the night;
I snooze at the Hummums till twelve, perhaps later,
I rattle the bell, and I roar up the waiter:
Your honor, says be, and then tips me a leg,
He brings me my tea, but I swallow an egg;
For tea in the morning's a slop I renounce,
So I down with a glass of the right cherry bounce.
With swearing, tearing, ranting, jaunting, slash∣ing, smashing, smacking, cracking, rumbling, tumbling;
Laughing, quaffing, smoaking, joking, swaggering, staggering;
So thoughtless, so knowing, so green and so mellow;
This, this is the life of a frolicksome fellow.
My phaet'n I mount, and the plebs they all stare,
I handle my reins and my elbows I square;
My ponies so plump, and as white as a lilly,
Through Pall Mall I spank it, and up Piccadilly;
Till losing a wheel, egad down come I smack,
So at Knightsbridge I throw myself into a back;
At Tattersall's fling a leg over my nag,
Thus visit for dinner, then dress in a bag.
With swearing, &c.
I stroll round the garden, and call at the Rose,
And then at both Playhouses pop in my nose;
I lounge in the lobby, laugh, swear, slide and swagger,
Talk loud, take my money, and out again stagger,
I meet at the Shakespeare a good natur'd soul,
Then down to our club at St. James's I roll;
The joys of the night are a thousand at play,
And thus at the finish begin the next day.
With swearing, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: There he goes. A pleasant brother, I must confess. I wish I had stayed at Paris. No soul to speak to here but the Bull family. Now if chance would but throw the handsome officer in my way that I saw at the opera.

L.HI: Search all the wide creation round,
Or earth, or air, or deep profound,
To some great universal end,
Power, sense, instinct, reason, tend;
'Tis love, sweet universal love!
Why Phoebus smile upon the morn?
Why lend a ray to Dian's horn?
Why flowers perfume the breath of spring?
Or why do birds on hawthorns sing?
'Tis love, sweet universal love!
With honour join'd, oh! form'd to bless,
Thy power let every heart consess;
If sense and reason but remove,
The bandage from the eyes of love,
Of love, sweet universal love!

DIV3.P: Deuce take the man! If his smiles were worth a thought, he'd have followed me to Fontainbleau.— Oh, temptation! yonder he comes—I must retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Indeed, Rosa, I'm glad you've not cscaped farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Ay, hold of that lady's arm.—I wonder women have no decency in public.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ha! yonder is the very charmer I saw at the Sunday opera at Paris. I must follow her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: If lord Winlove should follow, death to him or my brother must ensue.

DIV3.STAGE: Celia sings a few notes, and exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ah! my dear Rofa, I was afraid I had lose you. I am glad you have escape from that rogue—
Oh, my friend, I'm glad to meet a you—I rn so fast, and ask every body, all de little jockey Boys, and was so whip and kick about as I came across, dis big horse fiehl

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well, what do you want?—If I don't fol∣low her now, I may never see her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh, sir, I only forget to give a you your recept in your hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I suppose you mean I forgot to pay you your bill. Well, I shall be back in a moment. D'ye hear? take care of that lady, and don't quit her till my retum.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: What is he gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I hope he will never come back again, unless to pay me my bill.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Ay, I see that lady has a charm for him. Unkind Henry, to be angry with me for a passion your own heart is so susceptible of!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: My deare sweetest—

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Well, Sir, did you see the gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: What, the pretty gentleman that loves you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Every morning in my looking-glass.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Pshaw! have you seen the gentleman that enquired for me at your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh, you sly, little devil! You run away from the convent to von gentleman, in de mans coat, den from de gentleman to de officier; and now you want to be with the gentleman again.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: You're not much out there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh, you be von sly coquin.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: If lord Winlove and my brother should meet, I dread the consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: De capitaine is safe, dere is no danger (aside) he is making love to another lady. Let a me revenge his slighted vows —Oh! her skin is smooth as English broad cloth, soft as Genoa velvet! and her eyes are as bright as de polish of de Birmingham button. Oh! she's a pattern for a taileur's wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P:
It certainly will be the best way to see lord
Winlove, notwithstanding the impertinence of this fellow.—Well, sir, shall we go to your house?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: My house!—Yes, I see she loves me; and I adore the dimples of her pretty chin.

L.HI: Love does so run in my head,
Devil a stitch can I do;
From my jump out of my bed
Till my jump in it vid you.
Oh!
Sweet
Pet
Liver once cold as a cucumber.
Heigho!
Go,
Get away, littel Nannette.
Welcome, my bosom, a new comer,
Who like me loves you? oh, not a man!
My handkerchief, was I a great Ottoman,
Drops at your pretty toe.
Sweet Hen, in your beauties, I'll sun me,
Your twinkles and dimples have won me,
Den vink and smile pretty upon me,
Your game cock den vil I crow.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Charming woman! From the minute I first saw you at the opera house to this instant, I have not had a moment's happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Oh then, you think this a happy moment. I congratulate your good fortune, and leave you to the enjoyment of it

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Don't leave me. Permit me to follow. I'm a captive bound in your chains.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: And so, my captive would make his con∣queror a prisoner of war!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Thus then, I kiss the chains, and thus a∣dore—

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Oh, have a care, captain, you'll soil your regimentals.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Charming woman! I'm enchanted! char∣med with your vivacity!

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Was you never so enchanted, or charmed before, as you call it?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Enchanted and charmed, but never loved.

L.HI: Through circling sweets I freely rove,
And think my passion true,
But every charm that man can love,
Sweet love, I sind in you.
I will not boast with stoic pride,
That I've a heart of stone;
That I have often gaz'd and sigh'd,
To you I frankly own.
For circling sweets, &c.
That beauty bears a gentle mind,
The source of every joy,
Is now the hope I wish to find,
Then don't that hope destroy.
For circling sweets, &c.
For since that each external grace
Is by my fair possess'd,
In pity let ber mind keep pace,
And make her lover blest.
For circling sweets, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: If you are serious, pray walk it off that way, and I'll walk this. But if you really mean to meet in the field again, I'll send you a challenge by my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Your brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Yes, and then, in respect of what you men∣tioned, I—but no; you're conceited enough already.

L.HI: No hurry I'm in to be married,
But if it's the will of my brother,
I'd much rather stay;
Yet since in the way,
I as well may have you as another.
A strange custom this to be married,
Though follow'd by father and mother,
The grave and the gay;
But since in the way,
I as well may have you as another,
A prude though she long to be married,
Endeavours her wishes to smother,
I'd give you her nay;
But since in the way,
I as well may have you as another,

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Charming Celia!—Oh, here comes Sir Shenkin ap Griffin. As her brother is one of the turf, I'll just stop and ask if he knows her; and then for my siter Rosa.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin
SP.P: Give Winney a horn of milk, and let her here be crowned with misletoe, and let Jones play the harp before her, that every true Priton may rejoice at Winney's victories.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Your servant, Sir Shenkin. You saw that handsome lady that parted from me just now? Is not she very handsome?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes; she is handsome, like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I shall shortly call her mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: The tevil you shall!

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: The chief obstacle to our union is her thick-headed brother. Perhaps you may know him. He's one of the turf, and has not an idea in his head beyond a cock or a horse. But no matter for that; I'll have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Perhaps not. How dare you talk of my thick head? For fifty pounds, I have as many iteas in my head as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Here's a blunder! her brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, she is my sister; and that's your share of her (snapping his fingers) so my head may be ash, or oak, look you, or elm, or mahogany, or any wood you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: But, Sir Shenkin, hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Hold!—I've thought of a way. This may turn to my advantage. (aside)—Colonel Epaulette is a shentleman. He's tescended in a straight line from king Pippin the creat; but though a prince in politics, in affairs of jockeyship, he's no more than an ass. Look you, my Winney is to run his Joan of Arc to-morrow. Do you lay all the bets you can against her; for look you she shall lose, that is, my jockey shall lame her. I'll pay forfeit, and after the race we'll meet and share the cash like ho∣nest fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Sir Shenkin, honesty, generosity and pure sincerity of heart have ever been the characteristics of your country; but I find the pernicious practice of gaming is a decoy sufficient to seduce the honour even of a Welchman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: It may be so; but it's very good turf honour for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Then on or off the turf, I must beg leave not to be a scoundrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Why then, give over all thoughts of my sister; don't look at her. I have heard of your fighting a lord for your sister; so take care of me. Pistol pullets are not cherry-stones, and sharp swords are not green leeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I must seem to comply, or lose all hopes of Celia. I've thought of it, and I will punish him (aside). —Sir Shenkin, upon second thoughts I'll join you in this roguery.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Will you? then you are a damn'd honest fellow. So come along; my sister's your own, and she shall tell you so this minute. I'll leave you with her; and then for my own affair with miss Pull.—Pless her soul! how full of pusiness her is! what with marriage matches and slang matches— Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Devilish lucky I happened to meet with this English hotel: The mounsheers would have poisoned me else. My wife and daughter are making mademoiselles of themselves to pay a visit to this colonel Epaulette.—Oh! here they come.
Mademoiselle a la mode de Paris.—Hollo! George!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: What's the meaning of all this noise, Sir John?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Here, George, get me a pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: A pipe! What, do you think you're at Dobney's bowling-green?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Papa consider you are now at Fontainbleau, the very seat of elegance and fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Mrs. Casey, get me a ledger, and tan∣kard of porter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Fie, Sir John.—There now, he's at Gallaway's coffee-house. Sir John, do behave your∣self. You're not now at Margate, raffling for toys.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: No, nor dancing with your boots on at Dandelion, papa.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Do, get a little into the a la mode de Paris, I've sent for a French tailor to make you a suit of cloaths, that you may appear a little gay. The colonel may introduce us to the prince; but how would the prince be shocked at your appearance!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I don't think my appearance quite so shocking. No, my lady Bull. I think a British aldermen may stand before the first potentate in Christendom without shocking him.

L.HI: I'm here in France; the more fool I
To quit my beef and pudding;
At ton and taste you all will cry,
Oh yes, John Bull's a good' an.
In air or dress no travelld mac
Of joint shalt put my nose out,
At shrug and grin I've got the knack,
And see I turn my toes out. Toll, lol, lol, &c.
Gadzooks! so fine myself I'll rig,
That nobody shall know me;
My stining pate I'll straight unwig,
In silk mounseer shall sow me.
My arm shall squeeze a chapeau bras,
No more I'll block my beaver;
I'll stare and cock my opera glass,
And, so monstrous clever. Toll, lol, lol, &c.
I'll take a lady to the ball,
And lest that I should shock her,
My head I'll puff with Mareschal,
And to my back a knocker.
To make my fist appear a hand,
I'll draw on gloves of chicken,
While the cassino plays the band,
And cotillons we're kicking. Toll, lol, lol, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Servant.
SP.P: Mr. Lackland, sir, desires to be admitted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, shew the poor fellow up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: There's a pretty fellow indeed! And you, Sir John, to come to France, to get acquainted with your countrymen—and such shabby—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Shabby! eh! does that look like shabby? —What, you've recovered the arables again, or have you met with another fool from Throgmorton-street?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Do, be quiet, Bull.—Ladies, your most obedient. Don't let my appearance disconcert any body. I am just come from my friend Colonel Epaulette. He begged I would give his compli∣ments, and he'll wait on you presently.—That's a monstrous fine girl, Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Who, Doll? She's a damn'd fine girl. Ay, and I shall give fourscore thousand pounds with Doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Fourscore thousand!—a good hint. Oh yes, I'll marry Doll; but then that cursed mechanic—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Summons the graces, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P:
Oh dear! the powder's all gone. What
shell I do? I wish I could get a barber to titivate me up a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Pray, Bull, did not you keep a shop once?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, fifteen years; the Grasshopper upon Garlick-hill

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Garlick-hill! And perhaps you sold raisins?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Raisins! ay, and figs too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Pho!—Figs!—Yes, I'll marry her, though she's a dowdy, and her father a seller of figs.—Do, sit down. Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Johr.
SP.P: Sit down! No, I won't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Miss—miss—you're handsome, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Lord! I like him monstrously.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: No—I believe I had best speak first of all to the mother. Know—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, do you know—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Prythee, be quiet, Bull.—Madam, you're monstrously well dressed. It would be cifficult to say, whether the person ornaments the dress, or the dress the person.—This lady (to Dolly) is the picture of true English liberty; and you are from top to toe the madame Ninon of France.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Dan-na-non!—The follow speaks French too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Madam, may I hope to have the honour of your hand at the ball?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, if you please, sir, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Yes! Why, have not you promised Sir Shenkin ap Griffin?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes; but I did not know this gentleman then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Miss, don't you remember I've promised you Colonel Epaulette shall dance with you? You should not be so forward with your yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: But perhaps the Colonel may not like me, or I may not like the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Consider, madam, if you had never said yes, this beautiful creature had never been the exact re∣semblance of her accomplished mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Oh, dear sir!—Lord! he's vastly well bred.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Eh! why, what the devil!—If Sir Shenkin comes shew him up immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Shew him up! Shew him out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I have been fighting your battles. I am glad you are come, or faith! you might have lost Doll.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Oh yes, I see if the grey mare is the better horse, I shall lose the field.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Madam (to miss) will you do me the honour of your lilly hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Look you, Mr. Lackland, her hand may be lilly, or tulip, or daffidowndilly, you've no pusiness with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Do you know who you are talking to?— Come, madam—If you insult me, you know I won't take it (feeling in his pocket). Do, Bull, step and fetch my spust-box out of the parlour—Sir Shenkin, if you mean to insult, you shall go out with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Mr. Lackland, my Lady Bull will go out with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: An impudent dog, to send me for his snuff-box!—Go out!—Pray, is not that one of your fighting phrases?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes; he's sery fond of it: And some∣times 'tis meat and drinks to him. With a pair of pistols he must be sery pretty company in a little room.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, he must be excellent company in a little room.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I don't know where you have been; but if you mean to marry Doll, you must look about you, my boy

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Ay, that you must, my boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir Shenkin, give me your hand. I'm so pleased at your winning the race, that if I had fifty daughters, you should have them all, though they had a plum a piece.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Thank you, Sir John.—But that's true—Look you, (taking his pocket book out) you owe me fifty pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes, fifty pounds that you lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Lost! I had a fifty pound note this morning. I hope I have not lost it out of my book. —Oh no; there it is; it's safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Then you may as well give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Give it you! for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Pecause you do owe it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Me! no; that's too bad. I never bor∣rowed fifty pence of you in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Pho! pho! You laid me fifty pounds on the race, and did lose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I remember I said I thought the brown horse run the fastest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: You laid me fifty pounds on my Winney, and Joan of Arc did peat her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Who I!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Yes. When I said she would lose, you said a done; and tone and tone is pet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Psha! psha! Damn your Winney! I never laid—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I say, cot pless her—why do you tam my Winney?—The bishop of Bangor, look you, durst not tam my Winney.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Hold your tongue!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Then why do you tam my Winney? Look you, Sir John, you laid me fifty pounds that my mare was the winning horse; and I always make it a rule to pay and receive all my tebts of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Honour! fie, fie!—What, do you think I'll give you fifty pounds, because one horse thrusts his nose farther than t'other?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Lord! give him fifty pound, pappa.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Doll, that fellow's a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Rogueries and honesty's are incom∣pataples. And look you, I'll pung you down, though you were pig pold eagle upon the top of Snowdon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: There! he calls your father a bald eagle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Sir John, you're to be my father; and look you, I will refer it to the jockey club, and then, if you don't pay me, I'll post you at Tattersall's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Eh! there's your fifty pound.—Come here, Doll. That's a rogue.—There, Sir Shenkin, by gaining fifty pounds, you have lost my daughter and forescore thousand. So, your servant, Sir Shenkin. —Post me at Tattersall's!—There now, you may post that at Tattersall's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: The peard of a leek and the peard of a goat for you! (hums a tune) a pretty commence! —Pless my soul! how hot it is!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Sir Shenkin, I have run away from the old fogrum.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Old fogrum! a pretty name that to give a father! I've a great mind to run away with mist Toll, to be revenged on old fogrum. It will he pretty retaliations.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Lord then! what signifies talking about him? Why don't you run away with me at once?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I'm going to colonel Epaulette's. His house is near the castle. Meet me there, look you, in half an hour; and then his chaplain shall make us two patchelors one married couple.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Indeed. I won't be married here though; for I've been told that the parsons are all popes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: You'll find an honest fellow in father Bluebottle, as he calls himself. Put however, if you toan't like it, I'll run away with you to Chychwechlyn; and on the morning of our marriage we shall have all our friends and neighbours under our windows to sing us merry miscellanies and epithalamiums of music; and there'll be the oboe, the drum, the trumpet, the marrowpones and cleafers, and pest of all, the harp.

L.HI: The morning we're married, how sunny and jolly,
The pridegreom Sir Shenkin, the pride Lady Tolly!
When rous'd by sweet clamour we open our peepers,
And Phoebus salute in our night-gowns and slippers;
Then under our windows musicians all come,
Play fittle, sweet hautboy, sharp flagelet, drum.
But till the harp's melodious tingle,
All is puff, rattle, squeak and jingle.
The cymbals they grind, and the basses they grumble,
Pianos and fortes, a delicate jumble.
All joy to your bonors. See, see how they flock,
Whilst cleaver and marrowpone go nick y knock,
Tantivy the horn tantara the trumpet
Sound, sound—while we swallow our coffee and crumpet.
But till, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Enter 1st Waiter from Mrs. Casey's House, meeting 2d Waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Wait.
SP.P: BOB, why do you go about so with your hands in your pocket, when you know the house is so full of company?

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Waiter.
SP.P: Why, mistress sent me for captain Huff, to see if he can bully this Lackland out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Waiter.
SP.P: Bully him out!—Faith! the captain's whole regiment would not do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Upon my soul, my friend shall do it. In∣deed, an he'll bully this Lackland out of the house. Faith! he shall be ousted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lackland.
SP.P: You impertiment scoundrels, no atten∣dance! —Pray, Mrs. Casey, why don't you turn these fellows off, and get civiler waiters?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P:
Civiler waiters! Upon my conscience, the lads are civil enough. Why don't you pay your score, and get out of my house, spunging upon my best customers, and strutting about in their old cloaths
like a Bashaw. There you are fairly copied down seven pages, and not a penny of money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lark.
SP.P: I'm the best customer you have. There is not a table in your house, on which I have not left the mark of a dice box. Is there a morning I don't or∣der a Sandwich, or a day I don't drink my four bot∣tles after dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: A how many do you pay for?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Well, that's my affair, not yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: Here, Bob, bring Mr. Lackland his bill. It lies in the bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Bill! what is the tide turned? Here, chamberlain, ostler, waiter!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Have you a man comes to your house, that calls about them like me, except my friends? When I'm gone, yo'll have no more carriages and coronets calling at your door. If I have you, your house will be ruined.

DIV3.STAGE: (The Waiter gives the bill to Mrs. Casey—Servants enter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: My house will be ruined indeed, if I have not money to pay my wine-merchant. Why don't you take up a brown musket, or the end of a sedan chair! instead of which, you strut about like a lord, and give yourself airs like a lord, and drink like a lord, and sweat like a lord, ay and—here's your bill, and I dare say, you'll pay it like a lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: Perhaps I may. What do you give me you cursed long pieces of paper for? Do you think a gen∣tleman has got nothing else to do but to lug about great lumps of damn'd heavy gold in his pocket, to pay you such ugly, long, cursed bills as these (tearing them) when Bob and you think proper to thrust them into his hands?—Here, you rascals, get my baggage, and send it to the lilly.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: D'ye hear? Carry it upon a china plate, for 'tis a nice affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Your honour will remember the waiter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cook.
SP.P: The cook, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Cham.
SP.P: I am de chamberlain.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: And de jack a de boots your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Get out, you rascal! I've no boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Casey.
SP.P: See how I'm used, because I'm a lone wo∣man. Why don't I marry!—Oh! I wish I had a bit of a man for your sake (looking after Lackland.) Ah! it was not always thus.

L.HI: Kilkenny is a handsome place
As any town in Shamrockshire;
There first I saw my Jemmy's face,
There Jemmy first beheld his dear:
My love he was a bashful boy,
And I a simple girl to see;
Yet I was Jemmy's only joy,
And Jemmy was the lad for me.
But Dublin city bore the bell
In streets and squares, and houses fine;
Oh! there young Dick his love could tell,
And there I told young Dickey mine:
For Dick he was a roving blade,
And I was hearty, wild and free;
He lov'd, and I his love repaid,
Then Dickey was the lad for me!
When Dover strand my happy lot,
And William there my love did crown;
Young Dick and Jemmy I forgot,
Kilkenny fair, and Dublin town:
For William was a gentle youth,
Too bashful, nor too hold was be;
He said be lov'd, and told me truth,
And William was the lad for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: No getting on this way. The road! take a purse—No, I never thought seriously of that. No, marriage—Miss Bull is to be had—Garlick hill— Oh! but even that requires a small sum, and I've nothing to set about it with. I think Henry would assist me with a trifle, bad as his finances may be. But where to find him—He's skulking about the town, thinking he has killed lord Winlove, a man, whom not an hour ago I saw alive and well. Mar∣riage then is my dernier resort.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Tell Sir John Bull I'll wait on him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Monsieur Lackland, I am angry—I am en∣ragec—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Well! what about?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap. .
SP.P: What about! I am not afraid, sir. De fine lodger that you did recommend—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: What! he has taken French leave I suppose!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I would take leave to put him into French prison if I could find him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Eh! a thought strikes that may raise the supplies, and put a few guineas into my pocket.—Ay, Lapoche, this fine officer, as we thought him, is no other than an impostor escaped from England in woman's cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: In woman's cloaths! Nothing but impostors. The nun I have in my house escaped from the con∣vent of Villeneuve in boy's cloaths.—In woman's cloaths! Ah den, if de captain is in woman's cloaths, it is the nun that is in boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: In boots! Why what the devil is he at now! —No, no, you're—But why the devil should I un∣deceive him?—You're right, my little Lapoche; they're both impostors.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: And why did a you not tell me a so before?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Why, I knew you'd find it out, you saga∣clous monkey! But what will you promise me if I put you into the way to get an hundred guineas?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh! I'll promise every thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Why then, you must know—come here— this officer (looking round) is no other than a fellow escaped from England for shooting a lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Shoot a lord! Oh de prosligate!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: And there's a hundred guineas reward on his head, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh! dis is lucky. De sly coquin! Why you not tell a me dis before?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Now I have told you, what will you give me for my intelligence?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I vill give a you fifty tanks ven I do get de money.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Thanks! Is that all? Have you got any cash about you? Come, come, let me touch five pieces now.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: De diable touch and take me if I do!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: No, then you are a scoundrel!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P:
Oui. I know I am ver great scoundrel, but I vill keep a my money for all dat. Five Guinea indeed! No, no, monsieur Lackland. I know a you too well for all that; but I must find out dis officier,
and that to me vill be de grand affaire. It vill get a me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Yes, a good beating, and I hope Henry will pay it you.—Then marriage is my last card. So Mifs Bull of Garlick hill, have at you and your four-score thousand pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Is your name Lapoche? If it is, you must come directly to Sir John Bull, or he'll send to somebody else.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh! for de suit of cloaths. I vill come di∣rect— Bless a me, I have more business than do grand financier.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Well will you come or no!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oui. Alons, monsieur.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Eh, what?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Dat is, go along, if you please,

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Oh! is that it? Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: You may tell Sir John Bull, and my lady Bull, and miss Bull, dat colonel Epaulette is come to vall on dem.

SP.SPEAKER: Waiter.
SP.P: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I suppose, from vat I am told, dis famille must be fine solis; but as dey were recommend from my good friend the duke, and as dey are En∣glish, I will shew dem every civility in my power.— Dis dress in de English style vill please a de young lady. I'm sure I am ver much oblige to monsieur backland.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Well, Robert, is the taylor coming?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Yes, sir; he's come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Is he? Then I'll be measured directly, (Exit Robert.) for my lady won't be easy till I get a suit of cloaths a la mode de Paris, as they call it. —Oh! this is the taylor I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir, your most obedient. I presume, sir, your name is Sir John a de Bull?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: At your service, sir Ay, ay, this is the taylor. Mr. Lackland mentioned you in very high terms.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I am ver much oblige to Mr. Lackland; and, sir, I shall be ver happy to render you any ser∣vice in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Very obliging truly! And I suppose you'll expect to be paid for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir, any obligation you do a me in return I shall consider as repaying; but sir, my good friend de duke—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: His good friend the duke!—Oh! he must be a very great taylor indeec!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I have de honneur to be ver dear to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! if you are so dear to your friends, to be sure your terms must be very high indeed to me. But come, I can't help it; so, take out your measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Measure!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, and out with your shears. Have you brought your book of patterns?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Vat do you mean? Book of pattern.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! I suppose he's too great a taylor to carry patterns. (aside) Yes, just that I may see your colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Colours! Oh ho, because I be in de army you take a me for an ensign? Do you suppose I carry de colour?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, I thought so, too great for that— pray now how many men may you employ?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: About a tousand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: A thousand journeymen! a damn'd great taylor indeed (aside)—A thousand men!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Yes, dat dere is my regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! what you work for a regiment, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Vat does he mean? Sir John, I am come to vait upon de lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! what you do business for the ladies too! Oh! you're a great rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Sir John, I know that you are privilege to joke by the custom of your country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: What you want the custom of my country. I can't promise you that, but you shall have mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: And, sir, from de recommendation I have had, I shall be proud to shew you all de civility in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Sir, I am very much obliged to you. Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I wish to shew you every respect, and vill introduce you to de prince—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: You introduce! introduced by a taylor! Ha! ha! Damme, that's too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Taylor, sir! I don't know vat you mean; but, sir, if you vas not English, your life—your life should answer this behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: My life! you need not be so hot, my little taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P:
I don't know, sir, whether you are fool by nature, or clown by habit. If de former, you are
beneath my notice: if de latter, I will have satisfac∣tion for dis gross behaviour to colonel Epaulette. But, sir, I vill instantly speak to my good friend Mr. Lackland; and den, sir, I vill be revenged for this affront.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Colonel Epaulette! Oh, the devil!— my Lady Bull! my Lady Bull!
My dear, here has been the colonel here, and I thought it had been the French taylor you sent for to take measure of me; and here has been the damn'dest mistake!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Mistake Colonel Epaulette for a taylor! Oh, Sir John, why will you ever attempt to speak to persons of distinction? Oh! it's like your blunders, to take a man of fashion for a taylor!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, they dress, and scrape, and shrug so much alike, that there's no knowing a prince from a pickpocket. But I'll order the chaise, and set out for Garlick-hill to-morrow morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Then you may go by yourself, Sir John; for my part, it would be monstrous for a person of my figure and deportment to leave the continental land without an introduction to the grand monarch. Call the colonel back.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Me—damme, I'd as soon call his regi∣ment as him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Robin! Robin!— (Enter Coachman.)— Desire that gentleman to walk up stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Gentleman! What the taylor, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Yes; the taylor, as your master calls him.— (Exit Coachman.)—Oh! what a blundering family! He thinks the colonel a taylor as well as his master.—Oh! here the colonel is.
Oh! sir, I blush to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Madam, I am your most obedient, very humble servant; but I thought Sir John was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Oh sir! Sir John is so hurt at his appearance—

SP.SPEAKER: Lap
SP.P: Oh! dat does not signify, madam. I vill foon equip him to make a better appearance

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B
SP.P: Sir, you're vasily obliging; but, sir, this mistake is all owing to having contracted such un∣fashionable habits—

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Never mind, madam. I vill give him de habit most fashionable.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Very kind indeed, sir. Oh sir, I'm sorry you have had such a loss to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Loss!—Oh yes, madam, I have lost my lodger.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Some friend, I suppose. Ay, he's too genteel to mind his loss of the race.—The running I mean—the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh, yes, madam, they are run away to make a de match!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Well, sir, I wish you better success with your Joan.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: My Joan!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: And, sir, we were told in Paris, that you were very much with the prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh yes, madam. I must lie a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: I am told you are a great man in the privy council, committees, and board of works

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Board of works—she means my shop-board.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Sir, I shall esteem it a particular favour, when it is convenient, if you will be kind enough to introduce us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Why, madam, I don't know that I can in∣troduce you to de head butler.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Butler! What does he suppose that we keep company with servants!—Ay, from Sir John's behaviour he thinks we are fit company for nobody else.
Sir John, I have been making all the apologies I can for you to the colonel there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: There!—Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: There.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Colonel there! Why damme, this is the real taylor.
SP.STAGE: (The taylor takes out his book of patterns.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: How! the taylor! (turns about) Ay, he is a taylor sure enough.—Arn't you ashamed, sel∣low? How dare you have the impudence to pass for a colonel? Heigh, sellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Miss, your mother would not call me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Her mother! Get out!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Oh! my dear, don't be angry with the young man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Get out with your patterns (pulls him off) my lady, I wonder you will under take to speak to persons of distinction. Not know a taylor from a man of fashion!

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Miss Doll's gone off, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Where is she gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: Mrs. Casey says, she thinks to be mar∣ried; for she saw her in close confab. with Sir Shenkin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: There's your Briton, Sir John.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But which way is she she gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Coachman.
SP.P: She went down towards Colonel Epaulette's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: There's your Frenchman, my lady!— Come along with me, Robin. Oh, for an English constable, or a search warrant.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, a Room at the Colonel's.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Oh miss, I do congratulate myself on de felicity of meeting you dus at home.—If I can carry her away, I shall be even vid her father for calling me a tailleur.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: But law, colonel, how shocking you're dressed!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Do you think so? Mr. Lackland said 'twas ver pretty my dear.—Oh! you be von lovely girl! how I do love you! Pray, miss, was you ever in love?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Oh yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Have a you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Only nine times. Let me see. Three times before I was out of my slips; twice while I was at Hackney boarding-school; once with my guitar master; then with Frank Frippery; then with Dicky Pettitoes. No, only eight; for I don't reckon the handsome stay-maker of Duck-lane.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Then be in love with me the ninth time; and scamper off with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Scamper with you! Why dont you ask fa∣ther's consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: No, it sound a so mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why, as you say, it does sound a little of Bow Bell. Well; and then it wl make a pure noise in the papers—the elopement—the pursuit— the marriage—the making up—Besides, I'm in love with your vis a vis. So come along; I'll scamper off with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Vel said, my little angel, come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: But hold—Will you excuse me to Sir Shenkin ap Griffin?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Excuse you to Sir Shenkin! for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Because I promised to run away with him; and I came here to meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Indeed! but you know I came a de first.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why that's true. And first come first served, as father says to his customers in the shop at home—Come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Hold, my dear, I must just step—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why I thought you was going to scamper off with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I shall soon be back—but as I don't know what may happen, I vill just order my man to put up de powder, de pomatum, and de dancing pump

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Well then, do make haste, colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I have prought the priest. He looks as merry as a pard and as smart as a truid.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: But why did you stay so long? I have been crying my eyes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Ton't cry, my tear. Wipe a your eye, ton't weep.—My dear, the chaise is ready for us, and a sulky for father Domine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly
SP.P: But must I desert the colonel for you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: To be sure you must. But I will put on a pair of jack boots, and trive you myself, for the poys here are as sluggish as their horses. They smack their whips, and they cry gee whu! but they are as slow as snails, though they gabble like turkey cocks.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Well, but come now, don't let us wait for the boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I'll be your postpoy, and trive you to Chychwechlyn, and as you was never married, how telighted you'll be with noises, and visits, and confusions!

L.HI: Tol lol, de rol, lol,
My Tolly, my Toll,
With me when you canter to Wales,
For petticoat white,
Buff breeches so tight,
Away go needles and flails.
Young Taffy throws by hur wheels,
Then Winney kicks up her heels,
With follow
And halloo,
And waddle
And straddle,
So merry to see us come;
With fiddle
And diddle,
In giggle
And wriggle,
They give us a welcome bone.
The joy so great,
So noble we treat,
An oxen is roasted whole!
And tho' on the lawn
The spiggot is drawn
For punch, you may swim in the bowl!
We give the ladies a ball,
We foot it away in the ball.
With follow, &c.
Miss Howell so nice,
And Lady ap Rice,
And cousin Sir Evan ap Floyd,
Parson Montgomery,
Counsellor Flummery,
ap Williams, Ap Floyd.
when the stocking is thrown,
I aoe;
Then follow, &c.
