SP.SPEAKER: Dolly
SP.P: So, one can't go without dancing pumps, and the other can't go without jack-boots. If any of my old sweethearts were to come in now, I should be inclined to give them both the double.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack
SP.P: So, at last I've found her.—Madam, your most obedient. Well, it's settled. I'll marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Marry me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Yes; but don't let your joy carry you away. I said I would.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Said! to who?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: To myself. And if a gentleman breaks his word with himself, who do you think he'll keep it with?—You're very handsome, my dear, that you are; and I would not tell a lie for all the women in France.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Lord! what a high notion of honour he has! and he's a much handsomer man than either Sir Shenkin or the Colonel—But my father says, that you arn't worth any thing, that you've no estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: That's a good joke i'faith! No estate! He might as well have said I borrowed a guinea of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: I'faith! and now I do think of it, he did say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Did he indeed? that's very diverting truly. Ay, and he might as well have said I borrowed these cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: That's what I thought of your fine cloaths, that you must have a great estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Not an acre. And to be sure I've no seat in Herefordshire—no parks—no orchards—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Orchards in Herefordshire! Then I dare say you make twenty Hogsheads of Cyder in a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Cyder—Oh! you accomplished—Garlick Hill—Yes; and he might as well have said that I've no house in Portman Square. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Portman Square! Oh dear!—then I shall live in Portman Square!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Ay, and without a guinea in the funds, or half a crown in my pocket at this moment. Ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Ha! ha! that's very true. Now then, will you answer me one question? If you was to agree to run away with me, would you wait for jack boots or dancing pumps?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Jack boots and dancing pumps! Not for the button of king Lewis's hat. You are frank and free. I love you; and thus I throw myself and all my fortunes at your feet. Now if we had but a parson and a chaise!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: There's one in the house, and t'other at the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Is there? Then my dear—Garlick Hill— come along.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Now, madam, now I'm for you; now I'm pistol'd and booted.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Come, Miss a de Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Come, Miss Pull, my tear.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Why, where is she gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Where did you put her?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Why, vat have you done vid her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I did leave her here.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Vell, and I did find her here.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir John and Lady Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Where's my child? where's Dolly Bull?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Dat fellow in de boots can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Come, come, none of your Welch tricks upon me. Give me my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: 'Tis that devilish Gaul has got her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Ay, you would not give your daughter to a Briton, and now you see she's snapped up by that Frenchman. But I'll Cressy and Agincourt you! Why, with Doll's fortune, I could build a man of war, and batter your breast-work. I'll come like the ghost of Hawke, and beat you! I'll be a Black Prince to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: You are much mistaken now, as you vas ven you took me for a tailleur. I tell you that postillion in boots has stole her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: No, no, I say 'twas you.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I say 'twas you.

L.HI: 'Twas you, sir, 'twas you, sir;
I'll thrash you black and blue, sir;
'Twas you that stole my daughter Doll;
'Twas you, sir, you.
'Tis true, sir, 'tis true, sir;
But this affront you'll rue, sir;
'Twas you that stole my daughter Doll;
'Twas you, sir, you.
Oh, Ma'am, no, ma'am, no, no, no, no, no, ma'am;
How can you wrong me so, ma'am?
I did not steal your daughter Doll;
But I know who.
No, sir, no, sir; no, no, no, no, no, sir;
How can you wrong me so, sir?
I did not steal your daughter Doll;
But I know who.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Diable! n'importe—Damme!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: This is frantics and insanities. But by the got of war, if I had you at home, you should give me satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Satisfaction!—I can a fight, or I can a let it alone. "I can fight and can conquer again and again."

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Got pless hur! I wish I had him at Tover, I'd teach him to conquer. You are now in your own house, and you may stay there. For my part, I've got on my boots, and I am resolved—I am resolved—to walk down stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh! what a bloody resolution!—stop the boots!

DIV3.STAGE: Exeunt Sir John and Lady Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: "I can fight, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Lord! how I do wish to get back again to England!—A girl like me to be a chambermaid, and to a taylor!—Well, I'm convinced if I'd as good cloaths, I should look as well as Rosa.

L.HI: When drest in all my finest things,
My gold repeater, bracelets, rings,
In toilet glass,
A lovely lass
I view, so gaily glancing;
I can't tell how,
But ne'er till now
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la,
And a ha, ha, ha!
You've set my heart a dancing.
The coach is come—down stairs we trip,
The Opera—Robin plies his whip,
What sparkling eyes!
Sir Fopling cries!
As to our box advancing;
I don't know how,
Yet ne'er till now,
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la, &c.
Sultana queen at masquerade,
Or nun, or humble village maid,
So fine, so bright
The sparkling night,
Like fairies nimbly prancing;
I don't know how,
Yet ne'er till now,
I felt my heart a dancing.
With a fal, lal, la, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I have de two imposteurs safe, if I can keep them.—So, mam'selle Nannette, you tink ver little of me. Noting vill serve a you but de English offi∣cier. Just now I was taken for Colonel Epaulette. You say I ugly. Never you tell a man he's ugly in his own house.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Lord, sir! I don't think you ugly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Don't you? Den I vill give a you de silk gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: No, sir, I never did think you ugly. I always, I always thought you very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Did a you?

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: I did indeed—as I hope for the silk gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: No, not prett—but very smart, comely—a very smart, comely, little fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Non.
SP.P: No, sir, very pretty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Vel den, pretty—a very pretty, little, smart fellow. But know, I have von grand affaire, great business, as good as hundred guinea; such discovery of my two lodger—

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Indeed, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ay, Nannette know nothing of de disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Miss Rosa rings her bell.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Stay. Where are you going? You are in a devilish hurry to get to de fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: Fellow! who do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: When the bell rung, why did you not send the girl to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Send a de girl? vat an impudent fellow!— Pray von you did take a my lodging, vas dat in de bargain?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: Nannette, will you step into my chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: No, indeed, she von't.

SP.SPEAKER: Nan.
SP.P: I was just coming, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Yes, she vas coming.—Get out of de room! Yes, she vas just coming—Get out of de room from de fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: I only want some powder.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: You shall get no powder or ball here. Fight∣ing fellow!—I vish he vas out of my house (aside.) If you want such cut-throat tings, vhy don't you go to your own Hyde Park? Dat's the best place for lord-shooting.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: How impertinent the fellow is! And lord Wilove to forsake me at such a time! For him I gave up all my peace of mind—But I'll ask pardon of heaven and my brother, and return to the convent.

L.HI: How can man such pleasure find,
Still in trying each endeavour
Thus to win the virgin's favour,
Softly steal into her mind,
And destroy her peace for ever;
With her heart,
To depart,
I eaving only grief behind.
Thus the boy, a linnet caging,
How engaging!
Now her sweet and warbling song,
Soon neglected,
All rejected;
Poor thing! she may her song give o'er,
Her sweetest notes can charm no more.

SP.STAGE: (Lapoche watches her off, then runs and locks the door.)
SP.P: Dere now I tink I have de bold capitaine safe. Now I have got lock up dis desperate fellow I have got de hundred guinea under my own key; and de diable a penny shall monsieur Lackland get. But I must go for de archer.—Here comes de nun in boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Well, sir; where is the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: De lady not far off. I fancy she may be found in boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: In boots!

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Yes. Don't a you feel yourself uncom∣fortable in boots?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: In boots!—Come, come, where is the lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: How finely I vas deceived to take you for a gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Pray, sir, what have I done to forseit that character?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: But pray a now, don't you find yourself un∣comfortable without de petticoat?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! will you fetch me one?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I dare say Nannette will accommodate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Very acommodating truly!—No, Mr. Frenchman; I have crimes enough already without adding the ruin of Nannette.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ruin! She may give you von you know; von can't ruin her.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Very commode indeed!—Yes, sister Rosa, you're got in a very pretty sort of a house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Pray—ha! ha!—pray—upon my vord, she looks vastly well in her boots.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Go, sir, do you banter?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Ay, and do you go to your chamber, child, and I vill send Nannette to you. Poor thing! I dare say ver fatigue.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Oh Rosa! She was my sister. Lord Winlove was a friend; and but for those uhappy misfortunes, for those fatal circumstances, my pros∣pects with Celia appeared so pleasing—how blest might I have been!

L.HI: Let fame sound the trumpet, and cry "to the war!"
Let glory re-echo the strain;
The full tide of honour may flow from the scar,
And heroes may smile on their pain.
The treasures of autumn let Bacchus display,
And stagger about with his bowl;
On science, let Sol beam the lustre of day,
And wisdom give light to the soul.
Let India unfold her rich gems to the view,
Each virtue, each joy to improve;
Oh, give me the friend that I know to be true,
And the fair that I tenderly love!
What's glory but pride? a vain bubble is fame,
And riot the pleasure of wine;
What's riches but trouble? and title's a name,
But friendship and love are divine!

DIV3.STAGE: Lapoche watches him off, then locks the door on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Vell said, Rosa—Dere now I have got yo both safe; and I have de archer ready for dis capitaine.—Oh! here be de gentlemam that came after the lady first.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Now I shall see Rosa's new flame.— Well, my friend, where is the captain that run away with Rosa?

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: What the nun in boots?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Nun in boots! I mean the officer that went off with the nun that you told me of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: I have him safe; but he's the diable of a fellow, and has been asking for powder; so have a de care.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Well, let's see this devil of a fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Shall I call in de archer? I have him ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Pho! Let me see the the captain. Open the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Yes, but I'll have de reward (opens the door.) —Dere— (runs round to the other door.) Now I'll see if my nun in boots is safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: My dear Rosa!

SP.SPEAKER: Rosa.
SP.P: My dear lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Celia .
SP.P: I only want to see the gentleman.

DIV3.P: I beg pardon. I want to speak with the gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Well, here are three gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Yes; but I want to speak with the English officer that lodges here—that is in custody.

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Oh! de nun in boots—more disguise. I dare say this is some English constable come over to take up de capitaine for killing de lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry .
SP.P: What do you mean by locking me in? Open the door, or I'll break it open

SP.SPEAKER: Lap.
SP.P: Break open my door! for shame, is dat be∣having like a nun?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Lord Winlove alive!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Yes, Henry. Are you sorry to see me?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Indeed, my lord, I am doubly happy to find myself guiltless of your blood, and you alive to do my sister that justice I'm sure you intend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Harry, my intentions were ever honour∣able; and that my immediate union with my Rosa shall evince. Your love for your sister hurried you to a rashness that was near proving fatal; but this cancels every error.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry
SP.P: My Celia!

SP.SPEAKER: Celia.
SP.P: Indeed I don't know how to apologize for this strange intrusion. Captain, don't be vain if I say 'twas on your account.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Sister Rosa, this happiness is unexpected. And now give me leave to introduce you to a lady, who intends shortly to honour our family with her alliance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Winlove, Henry, Celia, and Rosa.

L.HI: How sweet, how kind the joyful hours,
With peace and virtue crown'd!
They come like soft descending showers,
To cheer the landscape round
Hush, throbbing heart, as truth alone,
Should light the virgin's breast,
Retire, cold freezing doubt, begone,
Retire, 'tis love's request!

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dolly, Lackland, Sir John and Lady Bull.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Make haste or they'll catch us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Let's rally and face them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John .
SP.P: I know they are here. You're a pretty lady

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Softly, Bull; no abuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why damme, mayn't I speak to my own child?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Nobody, sir, must abuse my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Wife! I shall run mad! My daughter married to a fellow without a shirt! a fellow that borrowed a guinea of me this morning!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Ay, you would have an English husband! She may have married Barrington for aught you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: I hope he's a rogue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord W.
SP.P: Wish your son a rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: If he's myself I hope he's a rogue. I'll have no more mercy on him than the king of Prussia would have upon a Dutch alderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: So, Miss Toll, I hear you have made matches and matrimonies.

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes; so now you may canter off to Cychwechlyn as fast as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: Give you joy of your tom-tit; for she was never good, egg or bird.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Oh Dolly, how could you take up with such a person?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Why, the colonel could not go without dancing pumps, nor Sir Shenkin without jack-boots, so that I was very glad to take up with any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Very much obliged to you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: How do you all, good peoples? How does my lady Bull-dog! damme?—So, miss, you're married?

SP.SPEAKER: Dolly.
SP.P: Yes, and without waiting for dancing-pumps.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: Bull-dog! If you are a Frenchman, be∣have like one.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: I never will behave myself, damme!

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Colonel Epaulette, let me entreat you to leave off attempting the blunt honesty of the English. It only transforms your countrymen into brutes. The attempt is as ridiculous as for the rough English to ape the customs and manners of the French, where we ever miss the mark, and polish into puppies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin
SP.P: Well, you made the bets, when shall we share?

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: I don't understand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: No! I paid forfeit. Joan did walk over the course.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: And did you suppose I could behave so contemptible to join in such a scheme?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P:
It's fery well; you shan't have my
sister. Look you, I do desire that you will never speak to, look at, or think of Celia again.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Look you, Sir Shenkin, if you don't imme∣diately pay me the five thousand you laid me, and give your consent to my marrying your sister, I'll refer your conduct to the jockey club; and 'tis so notorious, that you'll not only be excluded the turf here, but at every race in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Why, my little Welchman, I am afraid you'll be posted at Tattersall's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: I'm nick'd, sous'd and slamm'd. Here, take my sister Celia. I'll back him against the field; for he has tricked me that have nicked hundreds.

SP.SPEAKER: Henry.
SP.P: Sir Shenkin, this is the first good I ever knew derived from gaming. For what sensation must that man be capable of, that builds upon the misery of others; and raises a fortune on the ruin and bank∣ruptcy of his fellow-creatures!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenkin.
SP.P: It may be so; but as I set out a young pigeon, I'm resolved to die an old rook.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: But how shall I get this rook out of my pigeon-house?

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel.
SP.P: Vell, monsieur Lackland, I have procured you a commission in my regiment; and 'tis much at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: I thank you, Monsieur; but while I can raise the price of a drumstick, I'll never pull a trigger or draw a sword against my native country.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Bravo! my boy. Give me your hand. And at dinner time you shall never want a nail in my parlour to hang your hat on. You shall post my ledger, and drive a gig.

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: Gig! Why you shall ride in a vis-a-vis, to the amazement of all Garlick hill.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Oh rare! My dear and I tide side by side in a vis-a-vis!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Shenhin.
SP.P: And look you, for all your under∣minings and circumventings, if you whip your tom∣tit down to Chychwechlyn, I'll give you a haunch of rock venison, and a pottle to wash it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir John.
SP.P: Rock venison!—Oh! he'll give you the leg of a goat.—Well now; as we seem now to be all tolerable good friends, we'll retire to the inn— (Lady Bull locks) Hotel I mean, where English hos∣pitality shall receive the zest of French claret.— Heigh! what say you to that, my antigallican son∣in-law?

SP.SPEAKER: Lack.
SP.P: With all my heart. But, sir, I'll have no illiberal prejudices in my family. National reflections are unworthy the breast of an Englishman; and how∣ever in war each may vindicate his country's honour. in peace let us not know a distance but the streights of Dover.

L.HI: Let fashion with her glittering train,
Abroad a while deceive us;
We long to see dear home again,
The love of England must remain,
And that can never leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Winlove, Henry, Rosa, and Celia.

L.HI: This patrist fire within each heart,
For ever let us nourish,
Moy England over flourish!
My future range,
The stock-exchange,
'Tis there I'll mind my paces;
Nor gig, nor nag,
Jack Bull shall drag
To French or English races.
At feast or ball,
At Grocers-hall,
'Tis there I'll mind my paces;
Yet nothing keep
Me from a peep
At French or English races.
Our bard still in your favour thrive,
His jokes your fancies tickling,
This boon in laugh and claps then give
To Shenkin of Cychwechlyn.
And now of each doubt and perplexity eas'd,
From Fontainbleau races we'll prance.
In hopes that all errors our friends will be pleas'd
To excuse, as 'tis "Our Way in France."
A patriot fire within each heart
For ever let us nourish,
Of glory still the golden mart,
May England ever flourish!

DIV1.HEAD: This Day is Published,
DIV1.P: By order of the Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty, in three volumes large octavo, illustrated with a volume in quarto of Plates, neatly engraved, Price One Guinea in boards, or 1l. 6s. bound.

A NEW EDITION of AVOYAGE TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN. undertaken by order of His Majesty, for making discoveries in the Northern Hemisphere, with a view to determine the position and extent of the West Side of North America, its distance from Asia, and the practicability of a Northern Passage to Europe.
Performed under the direction of Captains COOK, CLERKE, and GORE, in his Majesty's ships the Resolution and Disco∣very, in the years 1776, 1777, 1778, 1779, and 1780.

Written by JAMES COOK, Commander of the Resolution, and, from the time of his death, By JAMES KING, late Commander of the Discovery. The Maps and Charts are from original drawings, by Lieutenant H. Roberts, under the inspection of Captain Cook.
DUBLIN, re-printed for W. WILSON, No. 6, Dame-street. the corner of Palace-strees.
